newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli bonds end higher across the board.
newsitem.headline: Israeli bonds end higher across the board.

text.p: Israeli bonds closed higher on Monday as
traders continued buying both CPI-linked and unlinked bonds for the
consecutive second day, traders said.
Indices:
* Government bonds general: +0.09 pct to 111.55
* CPI-linked government bonds: +0.08 pct to 111.86
* Unlinked government bonds: +0.11 pct to 110.79
* Dollar-linked government bonds: +0.12 pct at 110.73
* Bank of Israel short-term Makam bills: +0.04 pct to 108.93
Volume including Makams was an average 198 million shekels ($56.5
million).

"Despite the relatively high July consumer price index (CPI, published on Friday) and expectations of a rise in interest rates at the end of the month, traders are buying unlinked bonds," said Ilan Doron of Solid Financial Markets.

"The market expects inflation for the next 12 months to be eight to 8.5 percent," Doron said. "With yields around 13 percent, unlinked bonds are attractive even if there is an interest rate rise at the end of the month."
The July index rose by 1.0 percent, at the low end of economists' expectations of 1.0 to 1.2 percent. In June, the CPI rose by 1.1 percent.

Doron said trading in CPI-linked bonds had been mixed with a positive trend. "Many institutional investors have to invest money in CPI-linked bonds. Also, there is a tight supply of these bonds, which is keeping the prices high," Doron said.
"We expect the Bank of Israel to raise interest rates by 0.5 percentage point on August 25," an investment manager at Israel Discount Bank said.
The base rate has been 12.7 percent since the middle of June.
Prices of dollar-linked bonds rose on Monday but amid very low volume, which Doron said reflected a lack of investor interest.
Note: Makams are zero-coupon unlinked certificates with durations of three months to one year. The Bank of Israel issues Makams to absorb liquidity.
($1 = 3.52 shekels)
